Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Justin Droba of Michigan State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Improving an already-novel modeling approach to laser frequency doubling via impingement upon metal surfaces," during the summer of 2012 at Osaka University in Osaka, Osaka-ken, Japan. The host scientist is Hiroshi Ajiki.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to improve an existing mathematical technique for modeling frequency doubling (second harmonic generation) of laser light by removing restrictive assumptions by taking a multi-physics approach. This represents an exciting step forward from a noveel existing model, which attempts to characterize the frequency doubling through the electron density of the metal surface that generates the phenomenon. This technique uses the orbital-free variant of density functional theory (DFT), a subfield of physics that is growing rapidly in influence and importance, in a truly interdisciplinary collaboration.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While I originally expected this project to be an ``expansion pack" to my main thesis research, instead, it has wholly transformed my approach and redefined the direction of my research. The originally proposed project was overambitious; rather, the solution we developed turned out to be much deeper and involved than I could have expected. This is perhaps the greatest result of my summer EAPSI project: in addition to accomplishing my primary goal, I obtained a treasure trove of new research directions.

Originally, the project had two goals: (1) improve an existing model; (2) develop a computational algorithms for that new model. The first goal was accomplished more than satisfactorily. Unfortunately, owing to the high number of intermediate calculations our new model requires, we were unable to finish the computations to the extent we had hoped. However, the foundation has been laid, and what had been intended as a subtle improvement to existing work has resulted in a total overhaul of my previous approach, a much stronger result than anticipated.

 

In addition to having an incredibly productive summer of research, I am pleased to say I was fully able to experience the wealth of culture and history of the Kansai area. Traveling only on weekends, I was able to visit over forty UNESCO registered sites, including all seventeen monuments registered in Kyoto, and fifteen of the seventeen non-trail sites comprising the "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range" entry. I was also fortunate enough to be able to attend the Hiroshima Peace Festival on August 6; my first visit to Hiroshima six years ago was a moving and life-changing experience. The memories I formed this year participating in the ceremony in Hiroshima Peace Park will carry with me until my mind can no longer remember.

 

However, the most valuable thing I got out of EAPSI, much more important than either my research results or the nice memories and photos of sightseeing, was the experience living abroad on my own for an extended period. In the biographical sketch portion of my application for EAPSI, I said that I ``have always been a little envious of the international students that come to the US" because the personal growth that comes with living in another country is tremendous. I have been fortunate to have been able to travel abroad many times for conferences, but those trips have only lasted a couple weeks at the most. After EAPSI, I am better equipped to understand my international colleagues much better, to relate to them on a personal level rather than an academic one. I feel a stronger bond with the world and feel much better equipped to prosper in our increasingly global society.
